page.title: 06ECOLOGY OF HOLYWELL
page.content: The area includes a variety of habit- ats,from the{mudflats}bounding the Dee Estuary to the N.E.of the town,to the {common}at Penyball 837ft above sea level,in the S.W.Predominantly small arable and livestock farms provide miles of well-established hedgerows. The wet areas of{reclaimed marshland, bordering the railway contrast with the drier{calcereous soils}of the hill areas.{Lush meadows and acid heaths possess their characteristic flora and fauna.Small areas of mixed woodland are scattered throughout the region. The{oakwoods}of the Greenfield Valley contain isolated{beech stands}which provide contrasting herb and shrub layers.Quarrying,mining,textile and copper mills have had detrimental effects.The lack of lichen attests to the present level of air pollution,but new wildlife habitats are increasing.
